rev.diff:
Line 81: Line 81:
==Protests==
==Protests==
â
===Cities===
  â
{{expand section|more cities needed, hasnt even covered whats on the death list. Or maybe remove section. Much of it is duplicated in the timeline entries|February 2011|date=February 2011}}
  â
<!-- For instance, I added the below locations, but 5 Feb 15:00, it was moved elsewhere, which could be reasonable:
  â
In addition, there were anti-regime demonstrations on at least the 4 Feb (the âDay of Departureâ) in the towns of Suez, [[Port Said]], [[Rafah, Egypt |Rafah]], [[IsmaÃ¯lia|Ismailiya]], [[Zagazig]], [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|al-Mahalla al-Kubra]], [[Aswan]] and [[Asyut]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12371479 Obama seeks quick Egypt handover], BBC News, 5 Feb 2011</ref>
  â
-->
  â   â
;Alexandria
  â
[[Alexandria]], the home of [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|Khaled Saeed]], had major protests and clashes against the police. Demonstrations continued and one on 3 February was reported to include 30,000 people.<ref>Al Jazeera news, 3 February 2011, approx 14:00 GMT</ref> There were few confrontations as not many Mubarak supporters were around, except in occasional motorized convoys escorted by police. The breakdown of law and order, including the general absence of police on the streets, continued through to at least the evening of 3 February, including the looting and burning of one the country's largest shopping centres.<ref>Reported by [[Wyre Davies]] of the [[BBC News]], 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:00 GMT</ref>
  â   â
;Cairo
  â
[[Cairo]] has been at the epicentre of much of the crisis. Most of the protests were held in downtown [[Tahrir Square]]. On the first three days of the protests, there were clashes between the central security police and protesters and as of 28 January, police forces withdrew from most of Cairo. Citizens then formed neighbourhood watch groups to keep the order as widespread looting was reported. The police were reintroduced to Cairo on the morning of 31 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013102845.html|title=Egypt Unrest and Protests Continue as Police Return to Cairo Streets|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Mansoura
  â
In the northern city of [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]] there were protests against the Mubarak regime every day from 25 January onwards. One protest on 1 February was estimated at one million people,<ref>Al Jazeera exclusive TV report, first broadcast 3 Feb 2011, 13.30 GMT</ref> while on 3 February, 70,000 people were reported on the streets.<ref>Stated by Professor Mohamed Ghoneim, interviewed on Al Jazeera, 3 Feb 2011, approx 19:30 GMT</ref>
  â   â
;Siwa
  â
The remote city of [[Siwa Oasis|Siwa]] has thus far been reported as relatively calm.<ref name="Sterling">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/03/egypt.protests.anxiety/|title=Across dusty Egypt, anxiety has filled the air|last=Sterling|first=Joe|date=February 4, 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> Local [[sheikhs]], who were reportedly in control of the community, put the community under [[lockdown]] after a nearby town was "[[Arson|torched]]."<ref name="Mistry">{{cite news|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/8823127.Family__cut_off__amid_Egypt_riots/|title=Mother from St. Albans Speaks to the Review from Egypt|last=Mistry|first=Manisha|publisher=''[[St. Albans Review]]'' (part of [[Newsquest]])|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Suez
  â
The city of [[Suez]] has seen the most violence of the protests thus far. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer|first=Daniel|url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/|title=Reports of 'Massacre' in Suez as Protests in Egypt Move into Third day|work=[[The Raw Story]]|date=14 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], the Tunisian city where protests started.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Luxor
  â
There were also protests in [[Luxor]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title=Egypt Travel Advice |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
;Sharm-El-Sheikh
  â
No protests or civil unrest took place in [[Sharm-El-Sheikh]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Stevenson, Rachel|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/31/egypt-sharm-el-sheikh-tourists-tension|title=Sharm El-Sheikh's Tourists Talking About a Revolution|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â  
===Timeline===
===Timeline===
{{split|2011 Egyptian protests|Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian protests|part=yes|discuss=Talk:2011 Egyptian protests#2011 Egyptian protests timeline|date=February 2011}}
{{split|2011 Egyptian protests|Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian protests|part=yes|discuss=Talk:2011 Egyptian protests#2011 Egyptian protests timeline|date=February 2011}}
Line 327: Line 300:
On this day in Cairo, protesters against the regime were numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
On this day in Cairo, protesters against the regime were numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
